Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: They said it correctly identifies problems with L.A. rent control and validates their demands for stronger limits.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: “The report shows that rent costs exceeding what tenants can pay is a primary cause of homelessness,”
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: They point to other L.A.-area cities that currently limit rent increases to less than 3% with no add-ons for utilities.; They said it correctly identifies problems with L.A. rent control and validates their demands for stronger limits.

Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: They strongly disputed the report’s conclusions.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: About 35% of the rent L.A. tenants pay goes to operating expenses for apartment buildings, on average.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The independent analysis found some of the city’s rules governing rent increases have favored landlords over tenants.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: From January 2020 through January 2023, 4 in 10 rent-controlled L.A. apartments became vacant.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The independent analysis found some of the city’s rules governing rent increases have favored landlords over tenants.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: Many expenses have risen sharply for landlords in recent years, outpacing inflation.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The independent analysis found some of the city’s rules governing rent increases have favored landlords over tenants.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: About one-fifth of L.A. renters are living below the federal poverty line.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The independent analysis found some of the city’s rules governing rent increases have favored landlords over tenants.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: According to U.S. Census data, just over half of those renters spend 90% of their income or more on rent.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The independent analysis found some of the city’s rules governing rent increases have favored landlords over tenants.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: The city’s current range of allowable annual rent increases — anywhere from 3% to 8% depending on inflation — is higher than the increases permitted in most other California cities with rent control.
Document Sources.Source Justification: The independent analysis found some of the city’s rules governing rent increases have favored landlords over tenants.

Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Apartment Association of Greater Los Angeles representative
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Landlord advocates strongly disputed the report’s conclusions.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Among cities that have elected to control rents — and not all cities have — Los Angeles appears to be tilted toward landlords.”

Named Person Sources.Source Justification: The report compares L.A.’s policies to other California cities.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “As we await the finalized version of this report, it’s heartening to see so much data supporting the policy changes that renters have been demanding — especially when it comes to preventing excessive rent increases that can devastate working families.”
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Soto-Martinez requested the report be commissioned.
